posts.title: Remembrance: AI Memory Companion for Alzheimer's Patients
posts.description: Remembrance is an emotionally intelligent AI memory companion for Alzheimer's patients that delivers reminiscence therapy through natural conversations.
posts.author: Reteena Team

content.text: Overview

Remembrance is an emotionally intelligent AI memory companion designed specifically for Alzheimer's patients. By storing memories in interconnected knowledge graphs that mirror how human memory actually works, Remembrance helps patients maintain their sense of identity and connection to their life stories even as cognitive decline progresses.
How It Works

The system delivers reminiscence therapy through natural conversations, allowing patients to engage with their memories in an intuitive and meaningful way. Our knowledge graph technology creates rich connections between memories, enabling patients to explore their life stories from multiple perspectives.
Impact

Early beta testing has shown promising results in helping patients maintain cognitive function and emotional well-being. We're excited to launch our private beta soon and continue refining this important tool.

posts.title: Low Field MRI Framework: Accessible Alzheimer's Diagnosis
posts.description: Enhances low-field MRI scans for Alzheimer's diagnosis using deep learning-based brain segmentation and volumetric analysis.
posts.author: Aarav Minocha, Ivan Ma, Jainish Patel, Seungyong Yang

content.text: Introduction

Our Low Field MRI Framework represents a breakthrough in accessible neuroimaging for Alzheimer's diagnosis. By leveraging deep learning-based brain segmentation and volumetric analysis, we enable accurate diagnosis using affordable, low-strength scanners.
Methodology

We developed a sophisticated deep learning pipeline that compensates for the lower signal quality of low-field MRI scanners. Our approach achieves 96% diagnostic accuracy while using equipment that costs a fraction of conventional high-field MRI systems.
Results

This work was published at IEEE BigData 2024 and demonstrates that high-quality neuroimaging for Alzheimer's diagnosis can be made accessible to healthcare facilities worldwide, regardless of their budget constraints.

posts.title: Lark: Multi-Stakeholder LLM Agents for Decision Making
posts.description: A biologically inspired decision-making framework that combines LLM-based reasoning with an evolutionary, stakeholder-aware multi-agent system.
posts.author: Dheeraj Chintapalli, Rikhil Tanugula, Sunkalp Chandra

content.text: The Concept

Lark is a biologically inspired decision-making framework that addresses the challenge of balancing multiple stakeholder perspectives in complex decision scenarios. By combining LLM-based reasoning with evolutionary principles, Lark generates aligned strategies that respect diverse stakeholder interests.
Architecture

The system employs plasticity, duplication and maturation mechanisms, ranked-choice aggregation, and compute-aware optimization to evolve effective decision strategies across multiple cycles. This approach mirrors biological neural development while maintaining computational efficiency.
Applications

Our work, presented at NeurIPS Workshop 2025, demonstrates how multi-agent systems can handle complex trade-offs while maintaining transparency and stakeholder alignment. The framework has applications across healthcare policy, resource allocation, and organizational decision-making.

posts.title: GeneAttentionNet: Biologically Informed Disease Classification
posts.description: A biologically informed neural architecture for Alzheimer's disease classification using gene expression data.
posts.author: Sunkalp Chandra, Gautham Korrapati

content.text: Motivation

GeneAttentionNet represents a new approach to disease classification that respects the biological reality of gene interactions. Traditional machine learning models often treat genes as independent features, ignoring the complex regulatory networks that govern cellular behavior.
Innovation

Our architecture combines attention-based tokenization, pathway gating, and protein-interaction-masked heads to capture gene-level context while maintaining biological interpretability. This approach improves accuracy over baseline models while enabling trustworthy, mechanism-aware predictions.
Future Directions

Presented at MIT URTC 2025, this work opens new avenues for transcriptomic disease modeling and biomedical research. We're continuing to refine the architecture and explore applications across other neurodegenerative diseases.

posts.title: CortiForge: Modeling Cortical Microcircuits
posts.description: An open-source, biologically grounded framework for modeling cortical microcircuits that links spiking neural network simulations with experimental brain data.
posts.author: Sunkalp Chandra, Gautham Korrapati, Dheeraj Chintapalli, S. Yang, Saketh Satti, Jainish Patel

content.text: Background

Understanding cortical microcircuits is fundamental to neuroscience research, yet existing tools often lack the integration between computational models and experimental data. CortiForge addresses this gap with a comprehensive framework for biologically realistic circuit modeling.
The Framework

Through standardized neuron libraries and AllenSDK integration, CortiForge provides end-to-end workflows that enable interpretable, validated circuit models. Researchers can build models that bridge theory, experiments, and neuroscience research at scale reproducibly.
Research Impact

Submitted to ICLR 2026, CortiForge represents our commitment to open science and reproducible neuroscience research. By making sophisticated modeling tools accessible to the broader research community, we hope to accelerate progress in understanding brain function.
